newsitem.title: USA: BEFORE THE BELL - Chips firm on book-to-bill news.
newsitem.headline: BEFORE THE BELL - Chips firm on book-to-bill news.

text.p: Shares in leading U.S. computer chip makers traded higher ahead of Wednesday's stock market open after the industry's key indicator supported a growing conviction that the chip market's slump is ending.
Intel Corp rose to 103-3/4 from 101-5/8, Texas Instruments Inc added 5/8 to 55-3/4, and Micron Technology Inc gained 1/16 to 31-1/2, traders said.

Following Tuesday's market close, the Semiconductor Industry Association said the North American book-to-bill ratio, which measures the value of orders against shipments, rose to 0.99 in September from a revised 0.93 in August.
The ratio means chip manufacturers received $99 in new orders last month for every $100 in shipments.
The September figure was the highest this year, reflecting a greater-than-expected increase in orders for computer chips.
Intel's advance was built on a rise to 103 in after-hours trading on Tuesday.
Elsewhere, Tellabs Inc stock was bought up vigorously after the electronic communications equipment company announced quarterly earnings last night that exceeded Wall Street forecasts.
Tellabs gained 5-1/2 to 78-1/2, a new year high, in pre-open trading, traders said.
Tellabs said its third quarter per share earnings were $0.50, up $0.08 from analysts' consensus estimate and up $0.20 from a year earlier.

In other pre-open trade related to the chip optimism, Cisco Systems climbed 3/4 to 65, Sun Microsystems rose to 66-1/4 from 65-3/4, Microsoft added 5/8 to 136, 3Com improved 5/8 to 67, and DSC Communications was up 3/8 to 15-7/16.
